Againſt the common enemy of virtue.

sp.speaker: Colu.
sp.l: Now have you finiſh'd? I have an inſtrument
Shall cure this noiſe, and fly up to thy tongue,
To murder all thy words.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: One little knot
Of phlegm that clogs my ſtomach, and I ba' done;
You have an Uncle call'd a Cardinal
Would he were lurking now about thy heart,
That the ſame wounds might reach you both, and ſend
Your reeling ſouls together. Now have at you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: We muſt not Sir be idle.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: What think you now of praying?

sp.speaker: Colu.
sp.l: Time enough;
Commend me to my friend; the ſcales are even,
I would be mercifull, and give you time,
Now to conſider of the other World,
You'l find your ſoul benighted preſently.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I'l find my way i'th' dark.

div.stage: They fight, and cloſe, Columbo gets both the ſwords, and Hernando takes up the ſeconds Weapon.

sp.speaker: Colu
sp.l: A ſtumble's dangerous.
Now ask thy life—Ha?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I deſpiſe to wear it,
A gift from any but the firſt beſtower.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I ſcorn a baſe advantage—ha.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I am now
Out of your debt.

div.stage: Columbo throwes away one of the ſwords. They fight, Hernando wounds Columbo.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Th'aſt don't, and I forgive thee.
Give me thy hand, when ſhall we meet again?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Never, I hope.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I feel life ebb apace, yet I'l look upwards,
And ſhew my face to heaven.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The matters done,
I muſt not ſtay to bury him.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: COlumbo's death doth much aflict the King.

sp.speaker: 2 Lo.
sp.l: I thought the Cardinal would have loſt his wits
At firſt, for's nephew, it drownes all the talk
Of the other that were ſlain.
We are friends.
I do ſuſpect Hernando had ſome intereſt
And knew how their wounds came.
His flight confirms it,
For whom the Cardinal has ſpread his nets.
He is not ſo weak to truſt himſelf at home
To his Enemies gripe.
All ſtrikes not me ſo much,
As that the Dutcheſs, moſt oppreſſed Lady,
Should be diſtracted, and before Columbo
Was ſlain.
But that the Cardinal ſhould be made
Her Guardian, is to me above that wonder.
So it pleas'd the King, and ſhe, with that ſmall ſtock
Of reaſon left her, is ſo kind, and ſmooth
Upon him.
She's turn'd a child agen; a madneſs,
That would ha' made her brain and blood boil high
In which diſtemper ſhe might ha' wrought ſomething.
Had been to purpoſe.
The Cardinal is cunning, and how e'r
His brow does ſmile, he does ſuſpect Hernando
Took fire from her, and waits a time to puniſh it.
But what a ſubject of diſgrace, and mirth,
Hath poor Celinda made herſelf by pride,
In her belief Columbo was her ſervant.
Her head hath ſtoop'd much ſince he died, and ſhe
Almoſt ridiculous at Court.
The Cardinal
Is come into the Garden, now—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Walk off,
It troubles me the Dutcheſs by her loſs
Of brain is now beneath my great revenge,
She is not capable to feel my anger,
Which like to unregarded thunder ſpent
In woods, and lightning aim'd at ſenſeleſs trees,
Muſt idly fall, and hurt her not, not to
That ſenſe her guilt deſerves a fatall ſtroke,
Without the knowledg for what crime to fright her,
When ſhe takes leave, and make her tug with death,
Untill her ſoul ſweat, is a Pidgeons torment,
And ſhe is ſent a babe to the other World,
Columbo's death will not be ſatisfied,
And I but wound her with a two edg'd feather;
I muſt do more, I have all opportunity,
(She by the King now made my charge) but ſhe's
So much a turtle I ſhall loſe by killing her,
Perhaps do her a pleaſure, and preferment;
That muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Is not this ſhe, that would be thought to have been
Columbo's Miſtreſs? Madam, his grace is private,
And would not be diſturb'd, you may diſpleaſe him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What will your worſhip wager that he ſhall
Be pleas'd again before we part.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'l ſay this Diamond Madam, 'gainſt a kiſs,
And truſt your ſelf to keep the ſtakes.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have long had an appetite to this Lady,
But the Lords keep her up ſo high— this toy
May bring her on.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: This interruption taſts not of good manners.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But where neceſſity my Lord compells,
The boldneſs may meet pardon, and when you
Have found my purpoſe, I may leſs appear
Unmannerly.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: To th' buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It did pleaſe
Your Nephew, Sir, before his death to credit me
With ſo much honorable favour, I
Am come to tender to his neer'ſt of blood,
Your ſelf, what does remain a debt to him.
Not to delay your Grace with circumſtance,
That deed, if you accept, makes you my heir
Of no contemptible eſtate— this way
Is only left to ty up ſcurrile tongues,
And ſaucy men, that ſince Columbo's death
Venture to Libell on my pride, and folly;
His greatneſs, and this gift which I enjoy,
Still for my life, beyond which term; a Kingdom's,
Nothing, will curb the giddy ſpleens of men
That live on impudent rime, and railing at
Each wandering fame they catch.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Madam, this bounty
Will bind my gratitude and care to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I am your Graces Servant.

sp.speaker: Car.

l.hi: Antonelli,

sp.l: And when this noble Lady viſits me
Let her not wait.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What think you my Officious, Sir; his grace
Is pleas'd, you may conjecture? I may keep
Your Gem, the kiſs was never yours.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sweet Madam—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Talk if you dare, you know I muſt not wait,
And ſo farewell for this time.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: 'Tis in my brain already, and it formes
Apace, good, excellent revenge, and pleaſant!
She's now within my talons, 'tis too cheap
A ſatisfaction for Columbo's death,
Only to kill her by ſoft charm or force,
I'l rifle firſt her darling chaſtity,
'Twil be after time enough to poyſon her,
And ſhe to th' world be thought her own deſtroyer.
As I will frame the circumſtance, this night
All may be finiſhed; for the Colonel,
Her agent in my Nephewes death (whom I
Diſturb'd at Counſell with her) I may reach him
Hereafter, and be Maſter of his fate.

l.hi: We ſtarve our Conſcience when we thrive in State.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Placentia, We two are only left
Of my Ladies Servants, let us be true
To her, and one another, and be ſure
When we are at prayers, to curſe the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I pity my ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: I pity her too, but am a little angry;
She might have found another time to loſe
Her wits.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: That I were a man?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: What would'ſt thou do Placentia?

sp.speaker: la.
sp.l: I would revenge my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: 'Tis better being a woman, thou mayſt do
Things that may proſper better, and the fruit
Be thy own another day.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Your wit ſtill loves
To play the wanton.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: 'Tis a ſad time Placentia,
Some pleaſure would do well, the truth is, I
Am weary of my life, and I would have
One fit of mirth before I leave the world.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Do not you bluſh to talk thus wildly?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: 'Tis good manners
To be a little mad after my Lady;
But I ha' done; who is with her now?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Madam Valeria.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Not Celinda? Ther's a Lady for my humour,
A pretty book of fleſh and blood, and well
Bound up, in a fair letter too; would I
Had her with all the Errata.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: She has not
An honorable Fame.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Her Fame? that's nothing,
A littie ſtain, her wealth will fe • ch again
The colour, and bring honour into her cheeks
As freſh; if ſhe were mine, and I had her
Exchequer. I know the way to make her honeſt,
Honeſt to th' touch, the teſt, and the laſt tryall.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: How Prethee?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Why, firſt I would marry her, that's a verb Materiall;
Then I would Print her with an Index.
Expurgatorius, a table drawn
Of her Court Hereſies, and when ſhe's read
Cum Privilegio, who dares call her Whore?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I'l leave you, if you talk thus.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: I ha' done,

sp.speaker: Placentia,
sp.l: thou may'ſt be better company
After another progreſs; and now tell me,
Did'ſt ever hear of ſuch a patient madneſs
As my Lady is poſſeſt with? ſhe has rav'd
But twice; and ſhe would fright the Cardinall,
Or at a ſupper if ſhe did but poyſon him,
It were a phrenſy I could bear withall;
She calls him her dear Governour—

div.stage: Enter Hernando diſguiſed having a Letter.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Who is this?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Her Secretary? Sir,
Here is a Letter if it may have ſo
Much happineſs to kiſs her Graces hand.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: From whom?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: That's not in your Commiſſion Sir
To ask, or mine to ſatisfie, ſhe will want
No underſtanding when ſhe reads.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Alas,
Under your favour Sir, you are miſtaken,
Her Grace did never more want underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: have you not heard, her ſcull is broken Sir
And many pieces taken out, ſhe's mad.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The ſad fame of her diſtraction
Has two much truth it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: If pleaſe you Sir
To expect a while, I will preſent the Letter.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Pray do
How long has ſhe been thus Diſtemper'd Sir?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Before the Cardinal came to govern here,
Who for that reaſon by the King was made
Her Guardian, we are now at his devotion.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: A Lamb given up to a Tyger! may diſeaſes
Soon eat him through his heart!

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Your pardon Sir,
I love that voice, I know it too, a little,
Are not you? be not angry noble Sir,
I can with eaſe be ignorant agen,
And think you are another man, but if
You be that valiant Gentleman they call —

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Whom? What?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: That kill'd, I would not name him if I thought
You were not pleas'd to be that very Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Am I betraid?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: The Devil ſha'not
Betray you here, kill me, and I will take
My death you are the Noble Colonel;
We are all bound to you for the Generals death,
Valiant Hernando? when my Lady knows
You are here, I hope 'twil fetch her wits agen,
But do not talk too loud, we are not all
Honeſt i'th' houſe, ſome are the Cardinals creatures.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Thou wert faithfull to thy Lady, I am glad
'Tis night, but tell me how the Churchman uſes
The Dutcheſs?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: He carries Angels in his tongue, and face, but I
Suſpect his heart, this is one of his ſpawns.
Signior Antonelli.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Honeſt Antonio.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: And how, and how—a friend of mine, where is
The Cardinals Grace?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: That will be never anſwered.

sp.speaker: Aut.
sp.l: He means to ſup here with the Dutcheſs.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Will he?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We'l have the charming bottles at my chamber,
Bring that Gentleman, we'l be mighty merry.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I may diſturb your jollity.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Farewell ſweet—

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Dear Antonelli— a round Pox confound you.
This is Court Retorick at the back ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Do you know this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: My Lady preſently diſmiſt Valeria,
And bad me bring him to her bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: The Gentleman has an honeſt face.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Her words fell from her with ſome evenneſs & joy.
Her Grace deſires your preſence.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I'l attend her.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: I would this Soldier had the Cardinal
Upon a promontory, with what a ſpring
The Churchman would leap down, it were a ſpectacle
Moſt rare to ſee him topple from the precipice,
And ſouſe in the ſalt water with a noiſe
To ſtun the fiſhes; and if he fell into
A net, what wonder would the ſimple Sea-guls
Have, to draw up the o'rgrown Lobſter,
So ready boild? he ſhall have my good wiſhes,
This Colonels coming may be lucky. I
Will be ſure none ſhall interrupt 'em.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Is her Grace at opportunity?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: No ſweet Madam,
She is a ſleep, her Gentlewoman ſays.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My buſineſs is but viſit, I'l expect.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: That muſt not be, although I like your company.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You are grown rich Mr. Secretary.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: I Madam, Alas!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I hear you are upon another purchaſe.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: I upon a purchaſe?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If you want any ſum —

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: If I could purchaſe your ſweet favour Madam?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You ſhall command me, and my fortune Sir.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have obſerv'd you Sir a ſtaid,
And prudent Gentleman— and I ſhall want—

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Not me?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: A Father for ſome Infant; he has credit
Ith' world; I am not the firſt caſt Lady
Has married a Secretary.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Shall I wait upon you?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Any whither.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I may chance lead you then—

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: I ſhall be honour'd to obey, my blood
Is up, and in this humour I'm for any thing.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Well Sir, I'l try your Manhood.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: 'Tis my happineſs,
You cannot pleaſe me better.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: This was ſtruck
I'th' opportunity.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: I am made for ever.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Dear Madam, do not weep.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Y'are very welcome,
I ha done, I wo'not ſhed a tear more
Till I meet Alvarez, then I'l weep for joy;
He was a fine young Gentleman, and ſung ſweetly,
And you had heard him but the night before
We were married, you would ha' ſworn he had been
A Swan, and ſung his own ſad Epitaph;
But we'l talk o'the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Would his death
Might ranſom your fair ſenſe, he ſhould not live
To triumph in the loſs, beſhrow my manhood;
But I begin to melt.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I pray Sir tell me,
For I can underſtand, although they ſay
I have loſt my wits; but they are ſafe enough,
And I ſhall have 'em when the Cardinal dyes;
Who had a Letter from his Nephew too
Since he was ſlain.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: From whence?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I know not where he is? but in ſome Bower
Within a Garden he is making Chaplets,
And means to ſend me one, but I'l not take it,
I have flowers enough I thank him while I live.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: But do you love your Governour?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Yes, but I'l never marry him, I am promis'd
Already.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: To whom Madam?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Do not you
Bluſh when you ask me that, muſt not you be
My Husband? I know why, but that's a ſecret;
Indeed if you believe me, I do love
No man alive ſo well as you, the Cardinal
Shall never know't, hee'l kill us both, and yet
He ſays he loves me dearly, and has promis'd
To make me well again, but I'm afraid,
One time or other he will give me poyſon.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Prevent him Madam, and take nothing from him.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Why, do you think 'twil hurt me?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: It will kill you.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I ſhall but dye, and meet my dear lov'd Lord,
Whom when I have kiſt, I'l come again, and work
A bracelet of my hair for you to carry him,
When you are going to heaven, the poeſy ſhall
Be my own name, in little tears, that I
Will weep next winter, which congeal'd i'th' froſt
Will ſhew like ſeed-Pearl, you'l deliver it?
I know he'l love, and wear it for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: She is quite loſt.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I pray give me Sir, your pardon,
I know I talk not wiſely, but if you had
The burthen of my ſorrow, you would miſs
Sometimes your better reaſon; now l'm well,
What will you do when the Cardinal comes?
He muſt not ſee you for the world.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: He ſha'not,
I'l take my leave before he come.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Nay ſtay,
I ſhall have no friend left me when you go,
He will but ſup, he ſha'not ſtay to ly wi' me,
I have the picture of my Lord abed,
Three are to much this weather.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Madam, the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: He ſhall ſup with the Devil.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I dare not ſtay,
The Red-cock will be angry, I'l come agen.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: This ſorrow is no fable, now I find
My curioſity is ſadly ſatisfied;
Ha? if the Dutcheſs in her ſtragled wits,
Let fall words to betray me to the Cardinal,
The Panther will not leap more fierce to meet
His prey, when a long want of food hath parch'd
His ſtarved maw, than he to print his rage
And tear my heart-ſtrings, every thing is fatall,
And yet ſhe talk'd ſometimes with chain of ſenſe,
And ſaid ſhe lov'd me; ha, they come not yet;
I have a ſword about me, and I left
My own ſecurity to viſit death.
Yet I may pauſe a little, and conſider
Which way does lead me to't moſt honorably;
Does not the Chamber that I walk in tremble?
What will become of her, and me, and all
The world in one ſmall hour? I do not think
Ever to ſee the day agen, the wings
Of night ſpread o'r me like a ſable Herſe-cloath,
The Stars are all cloſe mourners too; but I
Muſt not alone to the cold ſilent grave,
I muſt not; If thou canſt Alvarez open
That Ebon curtain, and behold the man,
When the worlds juſtice fails ſhall right thy aſhes,
And feed their thirſt with blood, thy Dutcheſs is
Almoſt a Ghoſt already; and doth wear
Her body like a uſeleſs upper garment,
The trim and faſhion of it loſt. Ha?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: You need not doubt me, Sir, My Lady prays
You would not think it long, ſhe in my ear,
Commanded me to tell you, that when laſt
She drank, ſhe had happy wiſhes to your health.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: And did the Cardinal pledge it?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: He was not
Invited to't, nor muſt he know you are here.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: What do they talk of prethee?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: His Grace is very pleaſant
And kind to her, but her returns are after
The ſad condition of her ſenſe, ſometimes unjoynted.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: They have Muſick.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: A Lute only,
His Grace prepard, they ſay, the beſt of Italy
That waits upon my Lord.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: He thinks the Dutcheſs
Is ſtung with a Tarantula.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Your pardon.
My duty is expected.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Gentle Lady.—a voice too?

lg.head: Song within.
lg.l: S. Come my Daphne, come away,

l.hi: We do waſt the Cryſtal day;

lg.l: 'Tis Strephon calls. Da What ſays my love?
S. Come follow to the Mirtle Grove,
Where Venus ſhall prepare

l.hi: New Chaplets for thy hair.

lg.l: D. Were I ſhut up within a Tree,

l.hi: I'd rend my bark to follow thee.

lg.l: S. My Shepherdeſs, make haſt,

l.hi: The minutes ſlide too faſt:

lg.l: D. In thoſe cooler ſhades will I
Blind, as Cupid, kiſs thine ey.
S. In thy boſome then I'l ſtay,

l.hi: In ſuch warm Snow who would not loſe his way.
WE'l laugh and leave the world behind,
And Gods themſelves that ſee,
Shall envy thee, and me;
But never find
Such joys, when they embrace a Deity.

sp.l: If at this diſtance I diſtinguiſh, 'tis not
Church muſick, and the air's wanton, and no Anthem
Sung to't, but ſome ſtrange Ode of love, and kiſſes,
What ſhould this mean?— ha, he is coming hither,
I am betraid, he marches in her hand,
I'l truſt a little more, mute as the Arras
My ſword and I here.

div.stage: Enter Cardival, Dutcheſs, Antonelli, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Wait you in the firſt Chamber, and let none
Preſume to interrupt us.
She is pleaſant; now for ſome art to poyſon all her innocence.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I do not like the Cardinals humour, he
Little ſuſpects what gueſt is in my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Now Madam you are ſafe.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: How means your Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Safe in my Arms, ſweet Dutcheſs.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Do not hurt me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Not for the treaſures of the world, you are
My pretty charge, had I as many lives
As I have carefull thoughts, to do you ſervice,
I ſhould think all a happy forfeit to
Delight your Grace one minute; 'tis a heaven
To ſee you ſmile.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: What kindneſs call you this?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: It cannot want a name while you preſerve
So plentifull a ſweetneſs, it is love.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Of me? how ſhall I know't my Lord?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: By this, and this, ſwift Meſſengers to whiſper
Our hearts to one another.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Pray do you come a wooing?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Yes ſweet Madam,
You cannot be ſo cruell to deny me.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: What my Lord?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Another kiſs.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Can you
Diſpenſe with this my Lord? Alas I fear
Hernando is aſleep, or vaniſh'd from me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I have mock'd my blood into a flame, and what
My angry ſoul had form'd for my revenge,
Is now the object of my amorous ſenſe,
I have took a ſtrong inchantment from her lips,
And fear I ſhall forgive Columbo's death
If She conſent to my embrace; come Madam.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Whither my Lord?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But to your bed or couch,
Where if you will be kind, and but allow
Your ſelf a knowledg, love whoſe ſhape and raptures
Wiſe Poets have but glorified in dreams,
Shall make your chamber his eternall Palace;
And with ſuch active and eſſentiall ſtreams
Of new delights glide o'r your boſome, you
Shall wonder to what unknown world you are
By ſome bleſt change tranſlated; why d'e pauſe?
And look ſo wild? will you deny your Governour?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: How came you by that Cloven foot?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Your fancy
Would turn a traitour to your happineſs;
I am your friend, you muſt be kind.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Unhand me,
Or I'l cry out a rape.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You wo'not ſure?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I have been cozend with Hernando's ſhadow,
Here's none but heaven to hear me, help, a rape,

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Are you ſo good at underſtanding then,
I muſt uſe other argument.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Go to, Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Hernando, Murder, Treaſon, help.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: An army ſha'not reſcue thee, your blood
Is much inflam'd, I have brought a Lancet wi'me,
Shall open your hot veins, and cool your fever;
To vex thy parting Soul, it was the ſame
Engin that pinc'd Columbo's heart.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Help, Murder.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: Some ring the bell, 'twil raiſe the Court,
My Lord is murder'd, 'tis Hernando.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I'l make you all ſome ſport,—So, now we are even,
Where is the Dutcheſs, I would take my leave
Of her, and then bequeath my curſe among you.

div.stage: Enter King, Dutcheſs, Valeria, Lords, Guard.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How come theſe bloody objects?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: With a trick my ſword found out, I hope he's paid.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo
sp.l: I hope ſo to; a Surgeon for my Lord Cardinal.

l.hi: Hernando?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Iuſtice, Oh Iuſtice Sir, againſt a raviſher.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Sir I ha' done you ſervice.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: A bloody ſervice.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: 'Tis pure Searlet.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: After ſuch care to perfect my revenge
Thus banded out o'th' world by a womans plot?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I have preſerv'd the Dutcheſs from a rape,
Good-night to me and all the world for ever.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: So impious.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt true, Alvarez blood
Is now reveng'd, I find my brain return,
And every ſtragling ſenſe repairing home.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I have deſerv'd you ſhould turn from me Sir,
My life hath been prodigiouſly wicked,
My blood is now the Kingdoms balm; oh Sir,
I have abu'd your ear, your truſt, your people,
And my own ſacred Office, my conſcience
Feels now the ſting, oh ſhew your charity,
And with your pardon like a cool ſoft gale
Fan my poor ſweating ſoul; that wanders through
Unhabitable climes, and parched deſerts;
But I am loſt, if the great World forgive me,
Unleſs I find your mercy for a crime
You know not Madam, yet againſt your life.
I muſt confeſs, more than my black intents
Upon your honour, y'are already poyſon'd.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: By whom?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: By me,
In the revenge I ow'd Columbo's loſs,
With your laſt meat was mixt a poyſon that
By ſubtle, and by ſure degrees muſt let in death.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Look to the Dutcheſs, our Phyſicians?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Stay, I will deſerve her mercy, though I cannot
Call back the deed, in proof of my repentance,
If the laſt breath of a now dying man
May gain your charity, and belief, receive
This Ivory box, in it an antidote
'Bove that they boaſt the great magiſtrall medicine,
That pouder mixt with wine by a moſt rare
And quick acceſs to the heart will fortifie it
Againſt the rage of the moſt nimble poyſon,
I am not worthy to preſent her with it,
Oh take it and preſerve her innocent life.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.l: Strange, he ſhould have a good thing in ſuch readyneſs.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: This that which in my jealouſie and ſtate
Truſting to falſe predictions of my birth,
That I ſh dy by poyſon, I preſerv'd
For my own ſafety, wonder not, I made,
That my companion was to be my reſuge.

div.stage: Enter Servant with a bowle of Wine.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.l: Her's ſome touch of grace.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: in greater proof of my pure thoughts I take
This firſt, and with my dying breath confirm
My penitence, it may benefit her life,
But not my wounds; oh haſten to preſerve her,
And though I merit not her pardon, let not
Her fair ſoul be divorc'd

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: This is ſome charity, may it proſper Madam.

sp.speaker: Valeria.
sp.l: How does your grace?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: And muſt I owe my life to him whoſe death
Was my ambition? take this free acknowledgment,
I had intent this night with my own hand
To be Alvarez luſticer.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You were mad,
And thought paſt apprehenſion of revenge.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: That ſhape I did uſurp, great Sir, to give
My Art more freedom and defence, but when
Hernando came to viſit me, I thought
I might defer my execution,
Which his owe rage ſuppli'd without my guilt,
And when his luſt grew high, met with his blood.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.l: The Cardial ſmiles.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Now my revenge has met
With you my nimble Dutcheſs, I have took
A ſhape to give my act more freedom too,
And now I am ſure ſhe's poyſon'd, with that doze
I gave her laſt.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Th'art not ſo horrid?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Ha! ſome Cordiall.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Alas no preſervative
Hath wings to overtake it, were her heart
Lock'd in a quarry, it would ſearch, and kill
Before the aids can reach it; I am ſure
You ſha not now laugh at me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How came you by that poyſon?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I prepar'd it,
Reſolving when I had enjoy'd her, which
The Colonel prevented, by ſome art
To make her take it, and by death conclude
My laſt revenge; you have the fatal Story.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: This is ſo great a wickedneſs, it will
Exceed belief.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I knew I could not live.

sp.speaker: Surgeon.
sp.l: Your wounds, Sir, were not deſperate.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Not mortall? ha? were they not mortall?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: If I have skill in Surgery.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Then I have caught my ſelf in my own Engin.

sp.speaker: 2 Lo.
sp.l: It was your fate you ſaid to dy by poyſon.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That was my own prediction to abuſe
Your faith, no humane art can now reſiſt it,
I feel it knocking at the ſeat of life,
It muſt come in, I have wrackt all my own
To try your charities, new it would be rare,
If you but waft me with a little prayer,
My wings that flag may catch the wind, but 'tis
In vain, the miſt is riſen, and ther's none
To ſtear my wandring bark.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.l: He's dead?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: With him
Dy all deceived truſt.

sp.speaker: 2 Lo.
sp.l: This was a ſtrange impiety.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: When men
Of Gifts and ſacred Function once decline
From virtue, their ill deeds tranſcend example.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: The minute's come that I muſt take my leave too.
Your hand great Sir, and though you be a King,
We may exchange forgiveneſs, heaven forgive,
And all the world. I come, I come Alvarez

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Diſpoſe their bodies for becoming funeral;
How much are Kings abus'd by thoſe they take
To royall grace? whom when they cheriſh moſt
By nice indulgence, they doo often arm
Againſt themſelves; from whence this maxim ſprings,

l.hi: None have more need of Perſpectives than Kings.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.p: Mr. Polla'd, wher's Mr. Pollard for the Epilogue?
div.stage: He is thruſt upon the Stage, and falls.

l.hi: I Am coming to you Gentlemen, the Poet
Has help'd me thus far on my way, but I'l
Be even with him; the Play is a Tragedy,
The firſt that ever he compos'd for us,
Wherein he thinks he has done pretily,
And I am ſenſible; I prethee look
Is nothing out of joynt? has he broke nothing?
Nor Sir, I hope.
Yes, he has broke his Epilogue all to peeces,
Canſt thou put it together agen?
Not I Sir.
Nor I, prethee be gone, hum? Mr. Poet,
I have a teeming mind to be reveng'd.
You may aſſiſt, and not be ſeen in't now.
If you pleaſe Gentlemen, for I do know
He liſtens to the iſſue of his cauſe,
But bliſter not your hands in his applauſe,
Your private ſmile, your nod, or hum, to tell
My fellows, that you like the buſineſs well;
And when without a clap you go away,
I'l drink a ſmall-bear health to his ſecond day;
And break his heart, or make him ſwear, and rage,
He'l write no more for the unhappy Stage;
But that's too much, ſo we ſhould loſe; faith ſhew it,
And if you like his play, 'ts as well, he knew it.

div.head: A Catalogue of the Authors Poems already Printed

item.hi: The Changes, or Love in a Maze
The Ball, or French Dancing Master

div.p: A Maſque of the four Honorable Innes of Court, preſented before the King and Queens Majesty at Whitehall in the Banqueting houſe.
